title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SAN ANTONIO — On a night where the hardwood floor of the Alamodome felt more like a stage for a one-man masterpiece, David Robinson delivered a performance for the ages, single-handedly dismantling the Boston Celtics with a career-defining 41-point outburst to power the San Antonio Spurs to a 103-92 victory.

From the opening tip, it was clear Robinson was operating on a different plane. The Admiral navigated the Celtics’ defense with a devastating blend of power and finesse, his 41 points not just a number on a scoresheet but a relentless, quarter-by-quarter assault. He was an unstoppable force in the paint, commanding double-teams and still finding a way to dominate.

While Robinson was the undeniable sun around which the Spurs’ offense orbited, he was not without a crucial supporting cast. Sean Elliott provided a vital secondary scoring punch with 20 points, and the playmaking of Avery Bradley (14 assists) ensured the offensive machine ran smoothly, feeding Robinson in his spots of destruction.

The Celtics, valiant but ultimately overmatched, were led by Rick Fox’s 22 points and a strong 18-point contribution from Dino Radja. Yet, for every run Boston attempted to mount, Robinson had an answer—a thunderous dunk, a silky turnaround jumper, or a commanding presence on the glass that snuffed out any hope of a comeback.

This was more than a simple regular-season win. This was a historic night authored by one of the game’s giants, a 41-point declaration of dominance that reminded everyone in attendance why David Robinson’s name belongs among the basketball elite. The final score read 103-92, but the story was, is, and forever will be, The Admiral’s masterpiece.
